questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past 6 months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. He has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. He attends high school and is on the swim team. He also states that he lifts weights on a regular basis. His father has a disk herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's age and gender are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, the absence of symptoms such as morning back stiffness, limited range of motion, or improvement with exercise makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic lumbar pain that worsens upon exertion and reclining, positive step-off sign, bilaterally positive straight leg raise test, and a waddling gait in the absence of sensory and motor symptoms are consistent with spondylolisthesis. The two most common forms of spondylolisthesis are isthmic and degenerative. Isthmic spondylolisthesis is most prevalent in children and adolescents. Swimming and weight lifting, both of which involve repetitive hyperextension and rotation of the lumbosacral spine, further increase the risk of developing isthmic spondylolisthesis.

Degenerative spondylolisthesis occurs at L4–L5 and most commonly affects individuals over 50 years of age. Other forms of spondylolisthesis may be associated with congenital disease, trauma, bone fractures, and underlying bone pathology (e.g., Paget disease).
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Anterior displacement (green overlay) of L4 on L5 is visible (Meyerding grade II). In addition, there is degenerative disk disease with narrowing of the L4–L5 disk space (red overlay), as well as hypertrophic changes of the L5 vertebral body.

C) INCORRECT:

Scheuermann disease is a common cause of chronic back pain in children, particularly in boys. However, one of the hallmarks of this condition, kyphosis of the thoracic or thoracolumbar region, is absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Facet joint syndrome is a cause of lower back pain in older adults. Degenerative arthritic changes are thought to be the underlying mechanism, which explains its old-age onset. This patient's age is inconsistent with facet joint syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation is possible in young athletes due to repeated torsional stress placed on the lumbosacral spine and also manifests with a bilaterally positive straight leg test. However, it is more common in older patients, and neurological symptoms such as radicular pain (lumbosacral radiculopathy), dermatomal numbness or tingling, and weakness would be expected. In addition, this patient reports that his pain is worse when reclining, while the pain of a herniated lumbar disk typically improves in the supine position.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

The L4–5 disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

F) INCORRECT:

An overuse injury is possible in a young athlete and would manifest with pain and stiffness in a localized region of the back, most often in the soft tissues. Patients can typically recall a specific inciting event. The presence of a palpable step-off and a bilaterally positive straight leg raise test indicate a different cause of this patient's pain.
questions.hint: Two adjacent vertebrae that are displaced and at different levels on palpation constitute a positive step-off sign.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 63 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My back and legs hurt when I walk to the grocery store.”
History of Present Illness:


3-year history of low back pain

pain has worsened significantly over the past 6 months and now radiates from the lower back to buttocks and thighs

symptoms are relieved by sitting and exacerbated by walking; sometimes legs feel weak and numb after walking
previously used ibuprofen on occasion but now takes it up to three times per day

Past Medical History:

hypertension
hyperlipidemia

type 2 diabetes mellitus

Medications:

lisinopril
atorvastatin
metformin
ibuprofen
fish oil supplements

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
penicillin
Family history:
noncontributory
Psychosocial history:

quit smoking 15 years ago but previously smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years

retired nurse
lives with her husband

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.1°C(98.8°F)
85/min
16/min
145/85 mm Hg
98% on RA
162 cm(5 ft 4 in)
68 kg(150 lb)
26 kg/m2




Appearance: mildly uncomfortable
Skin: warm, dry, and intact; no rashes or lesions; normal turgor
HEENT: PERRLA
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Musculoskeletal: loss of lumbar lordosis on standing; paravertebral muscle spasm; hamstring tightness; pain is absent on forward flexion but present on lumbar extension
Extremities: well perfused; dorsal pedis pulses 3+ bilaterally
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; DTRs of lower extremities 1+ bilaterally; reduced tactile sensation of lower extremities bilaterally

Diagnostic Studies
x-ray of lumbar spine: shown

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) can manifest with chronic low back pain. However, while this patient's pain is relieved by sitting and exacerbated by walking and lumbar extension, pain in AS is independent of positioning. Moreover, patients usually present with morning stiffness that improves with activity. Finally, the x-ray of the lumbar spine would show syndesmophytes and vertebral body squaring, reflecting a so-called “bamboo spine,” which is not seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Marginal syndesmophytes (red lines) from ossification of the annulus fibrosis bridge multiple lumbar vertebrae (known as “bamboo spine”). So-called “shiny corners” (green triangles) at the superior and inferior margins of vertebrae represent reactive sclerosis in response to inflammatory Romanus erosions. Lower lumbar facet joints are fused (green lines).

B) INCORRECT:

Pars interarticularis instability and fracture (spondylolysis) causes isthmic spondylolisthesis. However, isthmic spondylolisthesis more commonly affects younger patients and the L5/S1 joint. Moreover, in this condition, an x-ray of the lumbar spine would show findings suggestive of spondylolysis (e.g., scotty dog with a collar sign).
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (45° oblique view)

The normal Scottie dog sign (green overlay) has a collar (red overlay) as a result of a defect in the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis).

C) INCORRECT:

Vertebral metastases can manifest with low back pain and if the metastases compress the adjacent nerve roots, pain irradiation and neurologic symptoms can also be present. However, x-ray findings consistent with vertebral metastases, such as a compression fracture, lytic lesions, or sclerotic lesions, would be expected rather than findings of spondylolisthesis. Moreover, the clinical course of the low back pain in a patient with cancer would be more subacute. Patients with vertebral metastases typically have a deep, aching pain that often occurs at night.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis is more common in elderly women and causes vertebral compression fractures, which can manifest with low back pain, similar to what is seen here. However, the clinical course of low back pain caused by an osteoporotic fracture is more acute/subacute. Moreover, the x-ray of the lumbar spine would show decreased bone mineral density and a fracture rather than findings of spondylolisthesis.
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

There is a chronic compression deformity (red dimension line) of the L4 vertebral body, with displacement (red overlay) toward the spinal canal beyond the posterior vertebral lines of L3 and L5 (white dotted line). Exuberant anterior osteophyte formation is visible at L3–4 (red dotted lines).

E) CORRECT:

Spondylolisthesis in elderly patients is typically caused by age-related degeneration of the intervertebral disc and facet joints, leading to joint instability, which, in turn, increases corrosion of these structures. This degenerative cascade eventually results in forward subluxation of the vertebra, characteristically affecting the L4/L5 joint. Degenerative spondylolisthesis is more common in women, most likely due to increased laxity and instability of the ligamentous apparatus associated with the female hormonal pattern. Young patients more commonly have isthmic spondylolisthesis, which is caused by bilateral spondylolysis usually due to repetitive microtrauma. Isthmic spondylolisthesis typically affects the L5/S1 joint and an x-ray can show a fracture line of the vertebral arch (e.g., scotty dog with a collar sign).
questions.hint: Chronic low back pain that is relieved by sitting and exacerbated by walking and lumbar extension is characteristic of spondylolisthesis. This patient's x-ray of the lumbar spine demonstrates ventral displacement (i.e., anterolisthesis) of the L4 vertebral body relative to L5. As anterolisthesis progresses, the vertebral body may compress lumbar nerve roots, manifesting with features of spinal stenosis (e.g., neurogenic claudication).

questions.text: A 16-year-old female gymnast presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening low back pain. The pain is more pronounced after gymnastics training sessions, especially during back-bending and twisting maneuvers. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. She reports no relief with over-the-counter pain medications. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness and increased muscle tension in the paravertebral tissue of the lower lumbar region without any neurological deficits. Lumbar spine x-ray is performed. The oblique view reveals a fracture of the pars interarticularis at L5. The lateral view shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Spondylolysis is a lytic defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch without vertebral displacement. This condition is commonly seen in young athletes who engage in sports that require repetitive hyperextension of the spine, e.g., gymnastics. Spondylolysis is often asymptomatic but can manifest with low back pain that is exacerbated by activities involving spinal extension. Spondylolysis can progress to spondylolisthesis, which involves anterior displacement of the vertebra and typically manifests with similar symptoms. Lumbar spine x-ray is used to confirm the diagnosis. The oblique view is used to detect spondylolysis, while the lateral view is used to detect spondylolisthesis, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

Spondylolisthesis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with exertion and spine extension and a pars interarticularis fracture seen on lumbar spine x-ray. However, x-ray would also show anterior vertebral displacement. Additionally, patients with spondylolisthesis may present with gait problems, signs of neurological involvement (e.g., radiculopathy, urinary or bowel incontinence), and a step-off sign on physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Spondylosis describes degenerative changes of the spine and may manifest with low back pain and localized tenderness in the lower lumbar region, but it typically affects older adults and an x-ray of the spine would show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing, osteophytes, and sclerosis. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with spine extension, but neuropathic claudication, an unsteady wide-based gait, and reduced lower extremity reflexes are usually expected. Furthermore, spinal stenosis commonly affects middle-aged or older adults. Lumbar spine x-ray typically shows degenerative joint changes, congenital abnormalities, or disk herniation. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation may manifest with low back pain, but patients typically present with pain that radiates to the legs and other symptoms of radiculopathy (e.g., paresthesia of the affected dermatome, diminished reflexes). Additionally, x-ray of the spine may show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing and osteophytes. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: The x-ray finding seen in this patient is also known as the Scottie dog with a collar sign.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents to the office with a 6-month history of back pain. The pain worsens with exercise and when reclining. His mother mentions that he waddles when he walks. He denies any trauma to the back or previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. He attends high school and is on the swim team. On questioning, he states that he lifts weights regularly. He does not report any bladder or bowel concerns. Physical examination reveals:

Normal sensation and muscle strength
Hypertonic hamstring muscles bilaterally
Iliolumbar ligament tenderness
Reduced lumbar lordosis
Anterior displacement of the L5 spinous process compared to L4
Radiating pain down the ipsilateral leg with passive leg raising

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's age and gender are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, the absence of symptoms such as morning back stiffness, limited range of motion, or improvement with exercise makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic lumbar pain that worsens upon exertion and reclining, a positive step-off sign, a bilaterally positive straight leg raise test, and a waddling gait in the absence of sensory and motor symptoms are consistent with spondylolisthesis. The two most common forms of spondylolisthesis are isthmic and degenerative. Isthmic spondylolisthesis is most prevalent in children and adolescents and typically occurs at the L5–S1 level. Swimming and weight lifting, both of which involve repetitive hyperextension and rotation of the lumbosacral spine, further increase the risk of developing isthmic spondylolisthesis.

Osteopathic manipulative techniques are used in the conservative management of spondylolisthesis with the goal of reducing lumbar lordosis, which transfers the load from the posterior aspects of the displaced vertebrae back to the vertebral bodies. While high velocity, low amplitude techniques are relatively contraindicated in patients with spondylolisthesis, soft tissue techniques (e.g., counterstrain and myofascial release), which aim to relieve strained lumbar paraspinal tissues, are better tolerated.
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Anterior displacement (green overlay) of L4 on L5 is visible (Meyerding grade II). In addition, there is degenerative disk disease with narrowing of the L4–L5 disk space (red overlay), as well as hypertrophic changes of the L5 vertebral body.

C) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation is possible in young athletes due to repeated torsional stress placed on the lumbosacral spine and also manifests with a bilaterally positive straight leg raise test. However, it is more common in older patients, and neurological symptoms such as radicular pain (lumbosacral radiculopathy), dermatomal numbness or tingling, and weakness would be expected. In addition, this patient reports that his pain is worse when reclining, while the pain of a herniated lumbar disk typically improves in the supine position.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

The L4–5 disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.

D) INCORRECT:

An overuse injury is possible in a young athlete and would manifest with pain and stiffness in a localized region of the back, most often in the soft tissues. Patients can typically recall a specific inciting event. The presence of a palpable step-off and a bilaterally positive straight leg raise test indicate a different cause of this patient's pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Scheuermann disease is a common cause of chronic back pain in children, particularly in boys. However, one of the hallmarks of this condition, kyphosis of the thoracic or thoracolumbar region, is absent in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Facet joint syndrome is a cause of lower back pain in older adults. Degenerative arthritic changes are thought to be the underlying mechanism, which explains its old-age onset. This patient's age is inconsistent with facet joint syndrome.
questions.hint: Anterior displacement of the spinous process of a vertebra on palpation constitutes a positive step-off sign. Radiating pain with passive leg raising indicates a positive straight leg raise test.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man who is an offensive lineman on his college football team reports a 2-month history of low back pain that began approximately 3 weeks after starting football practice. He has been able to play with the pain, but it has been getting worse. He initially felt the pain only after practice and games but now feels it all the time, except when sleeping.
The pain is left-sided more than right-sided and does not radiate into the legs. The patient reports no back pain before this recent episode, nor any morning joint stiffness. The pain has not improved despite self-treatment with rest and stretching.
Active and passive movement of the lumbar spine is painful, and the pain is exacerbated by extension and hyperextension testing, although range of motion is normal. Straight-leg-raise testing is negative bilaterally. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal.
Which one of the following abnormalities is most likely to be seen on radiographs (including oblique views) of this patient's lumbosacral spine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disk injury is typically characterized by pain radiating to the lower extremities and by numbness and tingling, none of which are present in this patient. Features of disk herniation are not readily visible on a radiograph.

B) CORRECT:

Spondylolysis of the lumbar spine is a frequent cause of low back pain in young athletes. Spondylolysis refers to a stress fracture in the pars interarticularis of the lumbar spine, a component of the posterior elements of the vertebra. The condition most commonly involves the L5 vertebra, often in athletes who participate in sports that involve repetitive lumbar extension or twisting, such as gymnastics and soccer, or in athletes who play specific sports positions, such as linemen in football.

The back pain almost always develops insidiously and worsens gradually, as in other overuse injuries. Physical examination usually reveals pain that is exacerbated by extension on one or both sides, typically worsening with hyperextension. Further evaluation of patients with suspected spondylolysis can include plain-film radiography, bone imaging with single-photon emission CT, or MRI.

Key learning point: An athlete with low back pain that is exacerbated by extension should be evaluated for spondylolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliitis is generally associated with morning stiffness and is not typically associated with painful movement of the lumbar spine. One of the most typical causes of sacroiliitis in young adults is ankylosing spondylitis, an inflammatory disorder, more common in men than women, that typically begins in early adulthood and can affect the spine as well as the hips and ribs, leading to fusion of the spinal vertebrae.

D) INCORRECT:

A vertebral body fracture is often the result of trauma or bone fragility (e.g., osteoporosis or malignancy). It manifests with pain in the area of the fracture (thoracic and lumbar being most common). Given this patient’s age and lack of an overt history of trauma, fracture would be unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Schmorl nodes are thought to be a herniation of the lumbar disc into the vertebral body. They can be seen on MRI or plain films. They are more commonly seen in older patients with degenerative spine disease but can be seen in younger patients as well.

F) INCORRECT:

Facet stress fractures are uncommon, and they typically manifest with pain on lateral flexion

questions.text:
A 15-year-old football player who is an offensive and defensive lineman reports a 2-month history of low back pain that began approximately 3 weeks after starting football practice. He has been able to play with the pain, but it has been getting worse. He initially felt the pain only after practice and games but now feels it all the time, except when sleeping.
The pain is left-sided more than right-sided and does not radiate into the legs. The patient reports no back pain before this recent episode, nor any morning joint stiffness. The pain has not improved despite self-treatment with rest and stretching.
Active and passive movement of the lumbar spine is painful, and the pain is exacerbated by extension and hyperextension testing, although range of motion is normal. Straight-leg-raise testing is negative bilaterally. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal.
Which one of the following abnormalities is most likely to be seen on radiographs (including oblique views) of this patient's lumbosacral spine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disk injury is typically characterized by pain radiating to the lower extremities and by numbness and tingling, none of which are present in this patient. Features of disk herniation are not readily visible on a radiograph.

B) INCORRECT:

Facet stress fractures are uncommon, and they typically manifest with pain on lateral flexion.

C) INCORRECT:

A vertebral body fracture is often the result of trauma or bone fragility (e.g., osteoporosis or malignancy). It manifests with pain in the area of the fracture (thoracic and lumbar being most common). Given this patient’s age and lack of an overt history of trauma, fracture would be unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliitis is generally associated with morning stiffness and is not typically associated with painful movement of the lumbar spine. One of the most typical causes of sacroiliitis in an adolescent is ankylosing spondylitis, an inflammatory disorder, more common in men than women, that typically begins in early adulthood and can affect the spine as well as the hips and ribs, leading to fusion of the spinal vertebrae.

E) CORRECT:

Spondylolysis of the lumbar spine is a frequent cause of low back pain in adolescent athletes, accounting for almost half of the diagnoses in adolescents who present to sports medicine clinics with low back pain.

Spondylolysis refers to a stress fracture in the pars interarticularis of the lumbar spine, a component of the posterior elements of the vertebra. The condition most commonly involves the L5 vertebra, often in athletes who participate in sports that involve repetitive lumbar extension or twisting, such as gymnastics and soccer, or in athletes who play specific sports positions, such as linemen in football.

The back pain almost always develops insidiously and worsens gradually, as in other overuse injuries. Physical examination usually reveals pain that is exacerbated by extension on one or both sides, typically worsening with hyperextension. Further evaluation of patients with suspected spondylolysis can include plain-film radiography, bone imaging with single-photon emission CT, or MRI.

Key learning point: An adolescent athlete with low back pain that is exacerbated by extension should be evaluated for spondylolysis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female gymnast presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening low back pain. The pain is more pronounced after gymnastics training sessions, especially during back-bending and twisting maneuvers. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury. questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lumbar spine x-ray is used to confirm the diagnosis. The oblique view is used to detect spondylolysis, while the lateral view is used to detect spondylolisthesis, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

Spondylolisthesis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with exertion and spine extension and a pars interarticularis fracture seen on lumbar spine x-ray. However, x-ray would also show anterior vertebral displacement. Additionally, patients with spondylolisthesis may present with gait problems, signs of neurological involvement (e.g., radiculopathy, urinary or bowel incontinence), and a step-off sign on physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Spondylosis describes degenerative changes of the spine and may manifest with low back pain and localized tenderness in the lower lumbar region, but it typically affects older adults and an x-ray of the spine would show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing, osteophytes, and sclerosis. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with spine extension, but neuropathic claudication, an unsteady wide-based gait, and reduced lower extremity reflexes are usually expected. Furthermore, spinal stenosis commonly affects middle-aged or older adults. Lumbar spine x-ray typically shows degenerative joint changes, congenital abnormalities, or disk herniation. Disk herniation may manifest with low back pain, but patients typically present with pain that radiates to the legs and other symptoms of radiculopathy (e.g., paresthesia of the affected dermatome, diminished reflexes). Additionally, x-ray of the spine may show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing and osteophytes. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old female gymnast who presents with a 6-month history of progressively worsening low back pain. The pain is worse after gymnastics training, particularly with back-bending and twisting movements. She denies any history of trauma or injury. Over-the-counter pain medications have not provided relief. On examination, there is localized tenderness and increased muscle tension in the paravertebral tissue of the lower lumbar region, with no neurological deficits. Lumbar spine x-ray is performed. The oblique view shows a fracture of the pars interarticularis at L5, while the lateral view is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation may manifest with low back pain, but patients typically present with pain that radiates to the legs and other symptoms of radiculopathy (e.g., paresthesia of the affected dermatome, diminished reflexes). Additionally, x-ray of the spine may show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing and osteophytes. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Spondylolisthesis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with exertion and spine extension and a pars interarticularis fracture seen on lumbar spine x-ray. However, x-ray would also show anterior vertebral displacement. Additionally, patients with spondylolisthesis may present with gait problems, signs of neurological involvement (e.g., radiculopathy, urinary or bowel incontinence), and a step-off sign on physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Spondylosis describes degenerative changes of the spine and may manifest with low back pain and localized tenderness in the lower lumbar region, but it typically affects older adults and an x-ray of the spine would show degenerative changes such as disk space narrowing, osteophytes, and sclerosis. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis may manifest with low back pain that worsens with spine extension, but neuropathic claudication, an unsteady wide-based gait, and reduced lower extremity reflexes are usually expected. Furthermore, spinal stenosis commonly affects middle-aged or older adults. Lumbar spine x-ray typically shows degenerative joint changes, congenital abnormalities, or disk herniation. This patient's fracture of the pars interarticularis suggests a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Spondylolysis is a lytic defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch without vertebral displacement. This condition is commonly seen in young athletes who engage in sports that require repetitive hyperextension of the spine, e.g., gymnastics. Spondylolysis is often asymptomatic but can manifest with low back pain that is exacerbated by activities involving spinal extension. Spondylolysis can progress to spondylolisthesis, which involves anterior displacement of the vertebra and typically manifests with similar symptoms. Lumbar spine x-ray is used to confirm the diagnosis. The oblique view is used to detect spondylolysis, while the lateral view is used to detect spondylolisthesis, which is not seen on this patient's x-ray.

Key learning point: Spondylolysis is a stress fracture of the pars interarticularis, commonly seen in young athletes with back pain worsened by extension and best detected on oblique lumbar spine x-ray.
questions.hint: The x-ray finding seen in this patient is also known as the Scottie dog with a collar sign.

questions.text: You are seeing a 14-year-old boy who presents with a 6-month history of back pain. The pain worsens with exercise and when reclining. He is a high school student and participates on the swim team. He also regularly lifts weights. On examination, palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area reveals that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When asked to walk, he has a waddling gait. Passive straight leg raising on either side causes pain radiating down the same leg. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Facet joint syndrome is a cause of lower back pain in older adults. Degenerative arthritic changes are thought to be the underlying mechanism, which explains its old-age onset. This patient's age is inconsistent with facet joint syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's age and gender are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis, the absence of symptoms such as morning back stiffness, limited range of motion, or improvement with exercise makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Disk herniation is possible in young athletes due to repeated torsional stress placed on the lumbosacral spine and also manifests with a bilaterally positive straight leg test. However, it is more common in older patients, and neurological symptoms such as radicular pain (lumbosacral radiculopathy), dermatomal numbness or tingling, and weakness would be expected. In addition, this patient reports that his pain is worse when reclining, while the pain of a herniated lumbar disk typically improves in the supine position.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic lumbar pain that worsens upon exertion and reclining, positive step-off sign, bilaterally positive straight leg raise test, and a waddling gait in the absence of sensory and motor symptoms are consistent with spondylolisthesis. The two most common forms of spondylolisthesis are isthmic and degenerative. Isthmic spondylolisthesis is most prevalent in children and adolescents. Swimming and weight lifting, both of which involve repetitive hyperextension and rotation of the lumbosacral spine, further increase the risk of developing isthmic spondylolisthesis.

Degenerative spondylolisthesis occurs at L4–L5 and most commonly affects individuals over 50 years of age. Other forms of spondylolisthesis may be associated with congenital disease, trauma, bone fractures, and underlying bone pathology (e.g., Paget disease).

Key learning point: Spondylolisthesis in adolescents presents with chronic back pain, a palpable step-off at the lumbosacral spine, positive straight leg raise, and a waddling gait, often associated with activities involving repetitive spinal hyperextension.
Image Description:

X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)

Anterior displacement (green overlay) of L4 on L5 is visible (Meyerding grade II). In addition, there is degenerative disk disease with narrowing of the L4–L5 disk space (red overlay), as well as hypertrophic changes of the L5 vertebral body.

E) INCORRECT:

An overuse injury is possible in a young athlete and would manifest with pain and stiffness in a localized region of the back, most often in the soft tissues. Patients can typically recall a specific inciting event. The presence of a palpable step-off and a bilaterally positive straight leg raise test indicate a different cause of this patient's pain.
questions.hint: Two adjacent vertebrae that are displaced and at different levels on palpation constitute a positive step-off sign.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman presents to the ED with worsening low back pain over the past week after joining the cheerleading team. She describes aching pain that occasionally radiates to the posterior thighs when standing upright, improving when she leans forward. She denies bowel or bladder symptoms, fever, or trauma. Examination shows normal strength and sensation in both legs. Lumbar extension reproduces her pain, but flexion relieves it. Straight-leg raise test is negative. Reflexes are symmetric. Vital signs are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Pain exacerbated by lumbar extension and relieved by flexion suggests isthmic spondylolisthesis due to pars interarticularis defects causing anterior slippage of one vertebra on another. Neurologic examination is often normal in low-grade cases. Initial evaluation includes lateral lumbar radiographs, with MRI indicated if radicular symptoms or neurologic deficits develop. Urgent neurosurgical consultation is warranted for patients with progressive weakness, sensory loss, bowel or bladder dysfunction, or evidence of high-grade vertebral slippage causing canal compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disc herniation typically causes radicular pain that worsens with forward flexion or sitting. This patient’s pain is provoked by extension and relieved by flexion, making mechanical instability rather than disc protrusion more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis causes neurogenic claudication and leg weakness precipitated by walking or prolonged standing. This patient's symptoms are localized to the back rather than the legs. Additionally, lumbar spinal stenosis is typically a degenerative condition of older adults, not adolescents.

D) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliac joint dysfunction produces localized buttock or posterior thigh pain but typically lacks the positional pattern seen here and is not aggravated specifically by lumbar extension.

E) INCORRECT:

Nonspecific back pain is common cause of acute low back pain but examination is normal. The extension-related exacerbation of pain suggests an alternate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female gymnast comes to an urgent care clinic because of progressive low back pain. The pain is a dull ache, is exacerbated by extension maneuvers such as back handsprings, and occasionally radiates to her buttocks. She does not have bowel or bladder dysfunction. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lower lumbar spine and marked hamstring tightness bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Focal tenderness directly over a spinous process
A palpable band of tightened paraspinal muscle
Lateral deviation of the spinous processes
Point tenderness over the sacroiliac joint
A palpable step-off between adjacent vertebrae

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tenderness over a spinous process could indicate a fracture of that process or an interspinous ligament sprain. Although the patient has generalized tenderness in the lower lumbar spine, this finding is less specific than a step-off. The history of pain with extension strongly suggests pathology of the pars interarticularis rather than an isolated spinous process injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraspinal muscle spasm is a common, nonspecific finding in many causes of low back pain, including simple muscle strain. Although this patient may have some associated muscle tightness as a protective mechanism, it is not the most specific or characteristic finding for the underlying bony pathology suggested by her history of extension-related pain and athletic activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral deviation of the spinous processes on palpation is a sign of scoliosis, which involves a rotational deformity of the spine. Although scoliosis can cause back pain, the hallmark feature in this patient's history is pain specifically with extension maneuvers, which is not characteristic of scoliosis. The clinical picture makes scoliosis an unlikely primary diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliac (SI) joint dysfunction can cause low back and buttock pain, particularly in athletes. However, SI joint pain is typically provoked by direct palpation over the joint or specific maneuvers that stress it, such as the FABER test. This patient's pain is clearly linked to lumbar extension, making a primary lumbar spine pathology much more likely than SI joint dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

Spondylolisthesis manifests with anterior slippage of one vertebra over the one below it, often due to bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis). On palpation, this manifests as a palpable step-off, where the spinous process of the superior vertebra is felt, followed by a depression before the more posteriorly displaced spinous process of the slipped vertebra below it is palpated. The slippage creates a discontinuity in the alignment of the spinous processes. This condition is common in young athletes who participate in sports that involve repetitive hyperextension, such as gymnastics. Hamstring tightness is a common associated finding and is thought to be a compensatory mechanism to stabilize the pelvis.
questions.hint: This patient's age, sport, and pain with extension raise suspicion for spondylolisthesis.
